citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One sheep was observed with an abnormally long outside lateral hoof. The animal's front right leg is bowed outward,
causing it to bear more weight on the inside hoof and leading to uneven growth of the two separate hooves. Excessively
long hooves can cause the animal discomfort and can contribute to potential lameness. The licensee must establish a
program with the attending veterinarian to ensure the use of appropriate methods to prevent and control diseases and
injuries. The licensee trimmed the animals hooves at the time of inspection.
*******Corrected during the inspection on June 12, 2025

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
Two alpacas were observed to be in an abnormally thin body condition. The weight loss had not been previously
communicated to the attending veterinarian. Various conditions could cause an animal to lose weight, such as illness,
parasites, etc. Abnormal health issues must be communicated to the attending veterinarian in a timely fashion, so that
appropriate veterinary care can be offered to the animal. The alpacas at the facility had recently been shorn on June 1 by
a contracted alpaca shearing service, in addition to receiving hoof and teeth trimming. The licensee contacted the
attending veterinarian at the time of inspection in order to discuss the animals' condition.

A section of the chain link fence for one of the goat enclosures was observed to be jagged with a sharp point. Some of the
fence was sagging from the support beam due to the goats climbing up on it. Jagged wire could cause harm to the
animals. The facility must be kept in good repair in order to protect the animals from injury. The licensee secured the
fencing and removed the jagged edges at the time of inspection.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with the licensee.
